data:
{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3300007,"name":"Ben","username":"Bzc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bzc/{size}/213635_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-02T02:49:48.037Z","cooked":"

Overview

After experiencing some weird behavior I created a test jig and measured the angles returned by the absolute output of two REV Throughbore encoders and found significantly out of spec error.

TLDR: 2 REV Throughbores appear to have a maximum absolute angle error ~10 times higher than the value specified in the datasheet and I have no clue why.

How we found it

We’ve been testing our MAXSwerve modules and noticed occasionally at least on of our modules would look slightly off on the steering angle. We did a quick diagnostic and discovered moving the module at 90 degree increments (referenced with a level) that at one increment the measured angle was ~2 degrees off the actual angle while it was accurate at the rest. Swapping the Throughbore actually caused this to become visibly much worse (didn’t measure but looked like 5 degrees).

Diagnosing the problem

To track down where the issue was I made a test jig and measured the angle error at 15 degree increments using just a Throughbore wired to a SparkMax with the absolute encoder adapter. The Spark was then connected to a computer via usb-c off robot and the angle read in REV Hardware Client.

Testing jig and methodology

The jig was as laser cut disk and pointer, the disk having marks at 5 degree increments. The Throughbore was bolted to the disk with a hex shaft through it with the pointer on the hex shaft. I’m quite confident the jig was more than accurate enough to indicate if the error was a serious as it initially appeared but I’d appreciate any concerns or criticisms.

image711×948 55.2 KB

Back side of jig (no wires attached)
image711×948 70.1 KB

Front side of jig

After assembling the setup there was no visible eccentricity or significant run-out, and I could not feel any backlash between the pointer and the encoder bore.

For each trial I begun by aligning the pointer to one of the four major angle marks and zeroing the encoder in the hardware client. The conversion factor was set to 360 so the reading in the hardware client was displayed in degrees. I then moved the pointer in 15 degree increments (I have limited time and sanity and was not prepared to do 5 degree increments) aligning it as best I possibly could by eye to the marks looking from a top down view to ensure no offset from perspective and recorded the measured angle in a spreadsheet. Each trial took points from the full rotation, ending back at the start to confirm it read 0/360 back at the start. Any positions with significant error (> ~3 degrees of error) were returned to after completing the trial to confirm the values were correct.

Trials

I ran 5 trials total. The total set of hardware tested was:

  • 2 Throughbores: #1 was the encoder from the original problematic module, #2 was brand new
  • 1 new JST PH 6-pin Extension Cable (long 6 pin to 6 pin ribbon cable)
  • 1 new 15 cm JST PH 6-pin Extension Cable (short 6 pi to 6 pin ribbon cable)
  • 1 new Absolute Encoder Adapter (used in all tests)
  • 2 SparkMaxes: #1 was newish use briefly for prototyping and #2 was taken fresh from the packaging

I also tested reverting firmware from 24.0.1 to 1.6.3 on the SparkMax.

Note: I did not try another adapter because a. it has no active components and b. it was already different than the one on the swerve drive.

Trial 1: Throughbore #1, long extension cable, SparkMax #1, 24.0.1
Trial 2: Throughbore #2, long extension cable, SparkMax #1, 24.0.1
Trial 3: Throughbore #2, 15 cm extension cable, SparkMax #1, 24.0.1
Trial 4: Throughbore #2, 15 cm extension cable, SparkMax #2, 24.0.1
Trial 5: Throughbore #2, 15 cm extension cable, SparkMax #2, 1.6.3

The Data

It appears that the error can be isolated to the encoders themselves. Encoder #1 had a peak error of 6.7 degrees and encoder #2 had a peak of 5 degrees. The error followed a similar shape between encoder #1 and #2. All runs of encoder #2 yielded extremely similar data (note the shift between trial 2 and trial 3 is due to the pointer being moved by one flat on the hex shaft (the data is shifted by 60 degrees, you can check if you don’t believe me).

Here is the measured error for trial 1:

Data: Encoder 1, Long Cable, Sparkmax 1 - Google Sheets

Here is the measure error for trial 2-5:

Rev Throughbore Error (Encoder 2)1110×686 65.2 KB

Data: Encoder 2 Combined Data Sets - Google Sheets

The datasheet for the sensor used internally suggests a maximum nonlinearity of +/- 0.5 degrees at room temperature which is far from the measured accuracy. @Greg_Needel could REV provide any insight on the accuracy you have measured or any potential causes of this problem?

The error appears to follow somewhat of a sine wave although there are 4 full periods from the first encoder but only 3.5 from the second encoder.

Another curious behavior that I ran out of time to collect data on was the change in values when the encoder was spun at a higher rotational rate than the slow movements between set points. Giving the encoder a few spins by hand seemed to significantly change the error at most or all data points (+/- ~4 degrees) although I cannot comment on there being any improvement to accuracy or pattern to this behavior.

Solving the problem

I’m not sure if this an isolated problem, but it seems that the other modules look correct and I can’t find any mention of this occurring online so I’d imagine so. I’d love to hear any suggestions for possible causes or other things to test and will continue to test myself. I plan to test one more encoder, characterize the change caused by spinning the encoder, and connect the sensor to a roborio to compare the absolute and relative outputs side by side.

Please share any thoughts, ideas, or experiences with similar problems.

No code. Just numbers straight from the rev hardware client.

Also worth noting that this data is in a weird status of having no known baseline. Hopefully the next encoder I test (probably one from the swerve that appears to be okay) will provide expected data and can be used as a baseline.

Make sure you don’t have stray magnetic fields – for example, it would be better to use an aluminum hex shaft, in case a steel one might be slightly magnetized.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-02-02T16:13:03.146Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":343,"readers_count":342,"score":148.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":453017,"topic_slug":"rev-throughbore-absolute-error-badly-out-of-tolerance","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/rev-throughbore-absolute-error-badly-out-of-tolerance/453017/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3300344,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-02T17:16:51.854Z","cooked":"

this is great work! error analysis is awesome!

here’s a great summary of sources of error for the type of sensor used

Tutorials | Rotation Angle Sensors | Products | Asahi Kasei Microdevices (AKM)

#06 Angular error of magnetic encoder | Tutorials | Rotation Angle Sensors |...

What's the cause of the angular error of the magnetic encoder? We will explain the causes of angular error of magnetic encoder and how to reduce the angular error. Part 6 of an encoder technical tutorial series by Asahi Kasei Microdevices (AKM).

none of the magnetic error sources I can think of would produce the 4x error period you’re seeing.

if the hall sensor front end were miscalibrated, maybe that would do it?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-02-02T17:16:51.854Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":315,"readers_count":314,"score":83.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":453017,"topic_slug":"rev-throughbore-absolute-error-badly-out-of-tolerance","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.akm.com/us/en/products/rotation-angle-sensor/tutorial/angular-error/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"#06 Angular error of magnetic encoder | Tutorials | Rotation Angle Sensors | Products | Asahi Kasei Microdevices (AKM)","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/rev-throughbore-absolute-error-badly-out-of-tolerance/453017/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3302991,"name":"Ben","username":"Bzc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bzc/{size}/213635_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-06T14:04:39.520Z","cooked":"

So haven’t had much time to do testing but I briefly tried a third encoder and much more interestingly two encoders on one shaft reading the relative and absolute outputs on a roboRIO.

I’ve got logs now (see bottom of post)

Third Encoder and Error Sources

So I grabbed a third encoder (also never used, bought this year) and put it in the jig. I made sure my hex shaft was aluminum as suggested by @nuttle. I didn’t take the time to record all the data because after randomly sampling a few data points the error was 3 or more degrees in a few places. At that point I was convinced either my testing methodology was bad, there was some external source of error, or I’m really not losing my mind and these encoders are not as accurate as they should be. I went to the other side of the building to test if there was any source of interference in our shop. No dice.

Comparing Relative and Absolute Outputs

So to test if there was some random issue with the pwm signal I connected the absolute and relative outputs to a roboRIO and logged the data. They were spot on minus a negligible amount of error (~0.15 max) which is attributable to differences in resolution between the two outputs, timing differences, etc…

image1555×942 43.2 KB

Absolute vs Relative Output over a range of angles (y axis in degrees).

Two Encoders On the Same Shaft

This saved my sanity.
I bolted two encoders together and put them on the same shaft. I separated them as much as I could to avoid their magnets interfering.

image713×950 65.5 KB

Encoder setup
image713×950 97.9 KB

Wiring to roboRIO (ignore the mess this is electrical’s training board).

With the absolute and relative outputs of both encoders wired to the DIO on the RIO I spun the shaft to generate some data.

image1555×942 49.4 KB

Blue and yellow are encoder 1, Red and purple are encoder 3.
The encoders follow each other closely for a majority of the rotation, but over certain regions separate to varying degrees. This particular peek in difference is just shy of 5 degrees. The difference doesn’t keep a consistent sign either.

At this point I have no idea what to do, but I’m pretty confident this issue is in fact real and not something I’m doing wrong. I’m emailing REV support this data and inquiring if they’ve done internal testing on the accuracy and have data they can provide or any insights on what may be wrong.

If anyone has any thoughts or similar experiences please share.

Log file and Code

Log file: Two_Encoders.wpilog - Google Drive
Code (minus imports and other files that are empty. I made a fresh blank project for this):

public class Robot extends TimedRobot {
  private Command m_autonomousCommand;

  private RobotContainer m_robotContainer;

  private DutyCycleEncoder newAbsolute = new DutyCycleEncoder(2);
  private DutyCycleEncoder badAbsolute = new DutyCycleEncoder(5);
  private Encoder newRelative = new Encoder(0,1);
  private Encoder badRelative = new Encoder(3,4);
  private double newZero = 0;
  private double badZero = 0;
  private NetworkTable table = NetworkTableInstance.getDefault().getTable("Encoders");
  private DoublePublisher newAbsPub = table.getDoubleTopic("3Abs").publish();
  private DoublePublisher badAbsPub = table.getDoubleTopic("1Abs").publish();
  private DoublePublisher newRelPub = table.getDoubleTopic("3Rel").publish();
  private DoublePublisher badRelPub = table.getDoubleTopic("1Rel").publish();
  

  @Override
  public void robotInit() {
    DataLogManager.start();
    m_robotContainer = new RobotContainer();

    try {
      Thread.sleep(2000);
    } catch(Exception e) {

    }

    newZero = newAbsolute.getAbsolutePosition();
    badZero = badAbsolute.getAbsolutePosition();
    newRelative.setDistancePerPulse(1.0/2048.0);
    badRelative.setDistancePerPulse(1.0/2048.0);
    newRelative.reset();
    badRelative.reset();
  }

  @Override
  public void robotPeriodic() {
    CommandScheduler.getInstance().run();
    newAbsPub.set(360*(newAbsolute.getDistance()-newZero));
    badAbsPub.set(360*(badAbsolute.getDistance()-badZero));
    newRelPub.set(360*newRelative.getDistance());
    badRelPub.set(360*badRelative.getDistance());
  }
}

Might be interesting to turn one of the two encoders upside down. It’s very striking how closely the two encoders on the same shaft track each other. Let us know anything else you learn!

I had it this way originally (compensating for the direction flip in code) but they were back to back and I was worried about the magnets interfering. I don’t have the log file on hand but it appeared to be basically the exact same behavior.

With the specified tolerances in the datasheet I’d expect the encoders to be within like 1.5 degrees max.

The tolerance on the encoders is +/- 0.5 so worst case that is +/-1 difference between the encoders and I would imagine an extra half a degree would cover any backlash, measurement error, or slightly out of spec sensor in the testing setup.

To my understanding (I’m a high school student so take that with a chunk of salt), the +/- 0.5 is the absolute position error at room temperature, +/-1.5 is at the extremes of the specified max and min ambient operating conditions, and the +/- 10% is on the relative output when spinning at 10,000 rpm which I think is essentially saying the position output can have +/-10% phase shift from the actual position when it’s spinning at a high rate of speed.

I’m pretty sure the +/- 0.5 number is most applicable in this scenario assuming the physical layout and characteristics of the encoder magnet(s?) are in spec for the sensor.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-02-06T15:23:45.041Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":170,"readers_count":169,"score":129.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":453017,"topic_slug":"rev-throughbore-absolute-error-badly-out-of-tolerance","display_username":"Ben","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":25951,"username":"Technologyman00","name":"Technologyman00","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/technologyman00/{size}/178178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54644,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 8727"},"post_url":"/t/rev-throughbore-absolute-error-badly-out-of-tolerance/453017/15","custom_user_title":"FRC 8727","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3303064,"name":"Technologyman00","username":"Technologyman00","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/technologyman00/{size}/178178_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-06T15:29:12.597Z","cooked":"
Bzc:

the +/- 0.5 is the absolute position error at room temperature, +/-1.5 is at the extremes of the specified max and min ambient operating conditions,

The way I read it is that the ±0.5 is the theoretical best at 25C

And ±1.5 is the expected value as it says -40C to 125C so it seems more of a range than limits
